Journal.Title: The Science of the total environment

Article.ArticleTitle: Regional distribution and environmental regulation mechanism of nitrous oxide in the Bohai Sea and North Yellow Sea: A preliminary study.

AbstractText: Nitrous oxide is one of the most powerful greenhouse gases and can destroy the ozone layer through photochemical reactions. In 2019, we conducted three cruises to study the spatial and temporal variability of N<sub>2</sub>O distribution and emissions in the Bohai Sea (BS) and North Yellow Sea (NYS), and analyzed the regional sources and sinks. The maximum average N<sub>2</sub>O concentrations were observed in the summer, followed by autumn, while the minimum was observed in the spring. The N<sub>2</sub>O concentration decreased in a gradient from the estuary to the continental shelf, particularly in summer, which indicated that the riverine input from the estuary was a strong source of N<sub>2</sub>O in the Bohai Sea. Due to the vertical mixing of the water column, the vertical distribution of N<sub>2</sub>O was moderate in autumn, while the bottom remained a hotspot for N<sub>2</sub>O emissions in spring and summer. The generalized additive model (GAM) showed that the temperature, salinity, DO and pH were strong predictors of N<sub>2</sub>O in the BS and NYS. Excess N<sub>2</sub>O concentrations were positively linearly correlated with the apparent oxygen utilization and NO<sub>3</sub><sup>-</sup> concentrations, which suggested that nitrification was the dominant process of in situ N<sub>2</sub>O production in the BS and NYS. The mixing of water masses, especially DW (diluted water) and BCW (Bohai Sea coastal water), provided a significant amount of N<sub>2</sub>O to the entire shelf area of the BS. In addition, the coastal input was a dominate pusher of N<sub>2</sub>O emissions in the estuarine region. Overall, the annual N<sub>2</sub>O emissions from BS and NYS were approximately 1.72 × 10<sup>-2</sup> Tg yr<sup>-1</sup>, which accounted for 0.51% of the annual global marine N<sub>2</sub>O emissions, but only 0.04% of the total area of the world's oceans. Hence, both the BS and NYS acted as N<sub>2</sub>O sources to the atmosphere.
